articles.headline: U.S. Raises Concerns About Israel’s Plan of Action in Gaza, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The Pentagon has sent officers to help the Israelis with the challenges of fighting an urban war.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon has sent officers to help the Israelis with the challenges of fighting an urban war.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is concerned that Israel lacks achievable military objectives in Gaza, and that the Israel Defense Forces are not yet ready to launch a ground invasion with a plan that can work, senior administration officials said.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Adam Entous and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Israel Intensifies Strikes on Gaza as Its Allies Call for More Palestinian Aid
articles.snippet: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
articles.abstract: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s military struck hundreds of targets in Gaza on Monday, in one of the biggest barrages yet of its war with Hamas and as a trickle of aid arrived for desperate Palestinians in the strip, where the lack of clean water, medicine and other critical supplies is fueling a dire humanitarian crisis.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and Alan Yuhas

articles.headline: New Normal or No Normal? How Economists Got It Wrong for 3 Years.
articles.snippet: Economists first underestimated inflation, then underestimated consumers and the labor market. The key question is why.
articles.abstract: Economists first underestimated inflation, then underestimated consumers and the labor market. The key question is why.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists spent 2021 expecting inflation to prove “transitory.” They spent much of 2022 underestimating its staying power. And they spent early 2023 predicting that the Federal Reserve’s rate increases, meant to cure the inflation, would plunge the economy into a recession.

articles.headline: How Columbia Sportswear Is Loosening Its Ties to Asia
articles.snippet: Confronted with the U.S.-China trade war and disruptions in the shipping industry, the company is shifting some production to Central America.
articles.abstract: Confronted with the U.S.-China trade war and disruptions in the shipping industry, the company is shifting some production to Central America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stan Burton wandered the Guatemalan factory like a prospector probing for buried treasure.

articles.headline: She Heeded Biden’s Warning to Migrants. Will She Regret It?
articles.snippet: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
articles.abstract: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
articles.lead_paragraph: They live in a rusty shack with no running water, hiding from the violence just outside their door, haunted by a question that won’t go away: Should they have listened to President Biden?
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios

articles.headline: Media Companies Eye Cricket-Loving Diaspora in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Investors are trying to capitalize on the relatively small — but loyal and growing — audience for the sport.
articles.abstract: Investors are trying to capitalize on the relatively small — but loyal and growing — audience for the sport.
articles.lead_paragraph: Right after morning prayers on a Saturday this month, members of the Masjid Quba mosque in Brooklyn joined a party.

articles.headline: The ‘Devil’s Playground’ of Urban Combat That Israel Is Preparing to Enter
articles.snippet: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
articles.abstract: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heavy fire from rooftops and booby-trapped apartments. Armor-piercing projectiles blowing up troop carriers. Fighters blending in with civilians, launching drone ambushes, or surging from tunnels full of enough ammunition, food and water to sustain a long war.

articles.headline: U.A.W.’s Expanding Strikes Could Signal an Endgame or a Long Struggle
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers on Tuesday expanded its strike to General Motors’ largest U.S. plant a day after striking at a Ram truck plant.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers on Tuesday expanded its strike to General Motors’ largest U.S. plant a day after striking at a Ram truck plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union shut down production at General Motors’ largest U.S. factory on Tuesday, significantly stepping up pressure on the large U.S. automakers as signs multiplied that the six-week strike is taking a toll on profits.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
